original_text: We are to interpret all Scriptural language literally, except when there is a compelling reason to consider it as figurative. Every figurative expression should be explained by its literal counterpart.

original_text: The language employed here is evidently symbolic, as evident in verse 17: 'These great beasts, which are four, are four kings which arise out of the earth.'

original_text: The implication of kingdoms, rather than merely individual kings, is discernible from the phrase, 'But the saints of the Most High shall take the kingdom.' In clarifying verse 23, the angel stated, 'The fourth beast shall be the fourth kingdom upon the earth.' Thus, these beasts symbolize four grand kingdoms.

original_text: The conditions under which they emerged, as represented in the prophecy, are also articulated in symbolic language.

original_text: The symbols introduced include the four winds, the sea, four immense beasts, ten horns, and another horn with eyes and a mouth, waging war against God and His people. Our task now is to discern their meanings.

original_text: In symbolic language, winds signify strife, political upheaval, and war, as articulated by the prophet Jeremiah: 'Thus said the Lord of hosts, Behold, evil shall go forth from nation to nation, and a great whirlwind shall be raised up from the coasts of the earth.
